reviews.review_text: First off I just want to say that ASW really knocked it out of the park with this port. Game looks fantastic and plays great online.  One thing that I'm amazed at is how awesome the training mode is for this game. They really teach you the VERY basics of how to go about playing this game. It's something that will ease beginning players in without having them feel overwhelmed by everything right from the get go. From there you've got a mode that teaches you combos and another mode that puts you in typical situations that you'll find yourself in from time to time while playing against opponents. Along with the is a very fleshed out freestyle training mode that they been offering us since 1998.  Online play seems pretty smooth right off the bat, although there are some who seem to be having issues with lobbies at the moment. Aside from that, playing in game is smooth. If there was lag then I'm oblivious to it. The few matches that I had so far felt great... Aside from me getting stomped into oblivion.   While some people will scoff at the number of characters in this game, I see nothing wrong with it as you can see ASW seems to have gone with quality before quantity. Every character has been animated in a way to replicate the animation frames from the older games. It's a joy just to sit back and just watch the characters, attacks, specials, instant kills, and intros/outros.   I haven't had the chance to try out Story, Arcade, or any other of the modes so far due to trying to learn Ramlethal at the moment, But as soon as I do, I'll make sure to update this review. But from what I've experienced you shouldn't even hesitate at spending your hard earned money on this. It even comes with a slew of goodies. Including an awesome soundtrack.

Guilty Gear Xrd is the most beautiful 2D fighting game utitlizing 3D graphics I've ever seen. Nothing can even compare to it. Street Fighter? Mortal Kombat? They can't even compare to the vibrant style of Guilty Gear. Much like how Guilty Gear X was a huge graphical achivement for 2D fighters back in 2000, Guilty Gear Xrd has set a new achivement for next gen fighting games.  Once you get past how mind blowing this game looks and get into the gameplay, it's very familiar. This game very much feels alot like classic Guilty Gear, they did a great job keeping the feel of the game very much the same. Utlizing Roman Cancels has been eased a great deal and are easier than ever to use, although some people may not apperciate the changes, particularly the slowdown during them, as well as how simple and even derp they can be this time around. I wasn't a fan of FRC's in the older Guilty Gear XX games, I felt they were just too hard to use and the new Roman Cancel system is alot easier to use, but maybe a bit too easy. It's not hard to really abuse this system and it can be quite obnoxious. It's hard to please both crowds though. Really the only new mechanic that I think really raises an eyebrow is Danger Time, which is just really silly and shouldn't of been in the game.   You can't discuss Guilty Gear without mentioning the audio. Most of the classic Guilty Gear sound effects are back, and the cast of characters sound great (In Japanese). I'm still not really used to most of the new character themes in the game yet, I liked alot of the original Guilty Gear X/XX soundtrack, but given time it'll probably grow on me.  Online Play can be either hit or miss as with most fighting games, but it's a good system allowing several games in one lobby to go on at the same time.  I'm looking forward to watching Xrd grow and bring back many classic Guilty Gear characters over the next few years.

It's the same great game as it is on consoles, with better graphics in-game, and some welcome changes for a PC port. The lack of in-depth options is dissapointing, and the game has quite a few minor issues that hurt this port. That being said, this port has fantastic netcode! I had 2F delay to somebody in Seattle! That's insane if you consider the before this I've only ever had 2F to a person living near me. For that reason alone, this PC port is a big step up for Arc System Works. It's not rollback, but it's pretty damn good. I recommend this game to anybody interested in fighting games (so long as you don't gush over Elphelt :^) )  I'll now list the issues I've discovered.     You can not change your resolution in full screen mode. Full screen is a seperate resolution option.    The games UI is from the PS3 port. The in game graphics are not, and neither is the hud. Unfortunately, this makes the menus look awful when upscaled to 1080p. They don't look very good at 720p either.    Anti-aliasing seems to have no effect. I can clearly see jaggy lines no matter which option I set my AA to.    There are no (obviously) usable configs within the games files. I can not change the settings to optimize it's performance on my system. (This is somewhat alleviated now thanks to a community guide showing me how to downsample from 4K resolution. Game looks pretty great and runs well.)    The game seems to be having memory issues for me. If I play the game for quite a while, the framerate will slow down between 30-50 and run extremely poorly.     The music may be of slightly lower quality than the music in the PS4 version. As well as this, the character attack sounds are kind of bad. Especially on Axl, I hear awful audio crackle. It's very obnoxious.    Player matches are very buggy at the moment, if a lot is going in in public lobbies there seem to be many issues causing players to vanish, be fighting no opponent, or just get kicked out of the lobby. It's a little tricky to play online right now. Ranked matches aren't fairing too well either, I can't play ranked right now due to a bug. The game will claim they declined the match almost instantly, but this happens with all players in ranked mode right now.  This issues aren't the end of the world, but I'm sure we'd all appreciate it if these problems were fixed.  Also, Elphelt should be removed from the game. Not really, but she just doesn't fit in with the cast if you ask me. Who won a competition to get their waifu OC in the game?

Performance: Great console/arcade port. I am not talking about the niceness of the anime style, but the overall graphic is simply flawless and stutterless,  anti-aliasing made it as if this game is especially made for PC. You'll notice the moment you play it, compared to 'other' simple console ported games, this one is alot well done.  Gameplay: Relative to many players. Unlike SF4 with extravaganza super moves that attract new players and then drop them off in the endless cliff of frame-specific combo, this game is quite linient in term of learning. This game might be fast paced, but it is still rhythmically (word?) easy to follow through. While this game offers 'instant destroy' moves, and this is the unique feature, it is not actually useful in real game, but it sure eye candies to see. Finally, the anime style cutscene within games is just a beautiful concept and also original!!  What make this game preferrable than other fighting game?: GG series have great seiyu (voice acting) since the very first game, I have yet to see other fighting game with that comparable aspect. GG series also have one of the greatest JRock soundtrack which somewhat suitable with the style. Thanks to Daisuke Ishiwatari (searchable from itunes/xbox). This game doesnt punish players for having their own playstyle, from button mashing, spamming fireballs (lol), to high speed cancel moves. So yeah, dont go to Vesper Arcade youtube channel, and then try to immitate what they do into your playstile.... just play with your own. (however, online battle might be so tough for some players)  I would recommend this game I might be biased, because I have been playing this series since PS1 and coin ops arcades, so yeah...

Ok, so I first saw this game on Friday Night Fisticuffs (a semi-weekly YouTube show on good fighting games, along with Saturday Morning Scrublords which covers the other side of the spectrum), and thought: -Well damn, that looks pretty awesome, I just might get that! While googling around I found a fascinating video from GDC (Game Developer Conference), where a developer (whose name I can't remember of the top of my head, sorry) talked about and showed the creation process behind the graphical style, which was the game's main selling point. The graphical style being anime with 3D models, which as far as I know is the first time it has been done in a game like this. Note that they even reduced the frames in the animations so it would look more like 'regular anime'. (I also found a price tag somewhere:59.99, whoa!)  Well then, as for the game itself. I'm just going to throw this out there, I have never played a Guilty Gear game before, and I've proven myself time and time again to be horrible at fighting games, so I am not really the best person to give this game a fair review.  What can I say, the game is fun, looks awesome, it's colorful, the soundtrack is pretty good and I guess it kinda' helps building the style of the game. The characters look awesome and the voice actors fit (admittedly, I have only played with the japanese voices 'cause I was recommended to do so, my inner weeaboo approves)  Like I said, awful at fighting games, so the first thing I go to is the tutorial, which just covers the basics, then goes WAY deep with the Roman cancels (which I forgot about, until I got the achievment by accident).  To conclude, as a game, neat. Probably wouldn't work as your first fighting game, barely worked as my second. Still, don't take it from me, I'm just over here semi-mashing my way through the arcade mode.

Strongly, strongly recommend this game after the multiplayer input bug gets fixed. Spent extensive time with this game on PS4.  Easily my favorite current-gen fighting game.  The Good:  Gorgeous graphics, incredibly fluid movement, mechanical depth, and good character playstyle variety.  Beautiful 2D sprite aesthetic (despite using 3D models).  Gameplay: Fun neutral game. Good input buffering for combos. No touch of death ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like MvC. Combos aren't boringly long like in Skullgirls/MvC. Less awful input correction than SF4.  The Bad:  Bug: game client starts getting frame lag and sound stuttering after about half an hour of multiplayer. Doesn't affect everyone, though. May want to wait for this to get fixed. UI Oversight: Using 720p assets for the in-game menus, instead of 1080. Makes the least important section of the game look grainy, but it's still sloppy.  Both issues are specific to the PC port. The PS4 version didn't have them.

When's Revelator?   Fast-paced and fun, Guilty Gear Xrd -SIGN- is a phenomenal 2D fighting game, featuring a cast of unique characters, a plethora of fun moves, and smooth gameplay perfectly complimented by fantastic music and great graphics. The game's art style uses 3D models, but deliberately makes everything look 2D in order to channel the feel of the older Guilty Gear games, even going as far as to make several of the attack animations intentionally choppy. Strangely enough, that choppiness actually makes this game look better. I don't understand it either.  Of course, by the time this game came out on PC, people were already clamoring for the second Xrd game, -REVELATOR-, and by the time  that  game releases on Steam we'll probably already have a third game in the works. This is still a very fun game, though. If there's one criticism I do have, it's that Arc System Works' games tend to not have the greatest netcode out there. The game's online functions well enough, but suffers from delay at times and doesn't seem to cooperate very well with streaming software, or at least it didn't for me.  Also the game has Elphelt Valentine and she is 150% cute so play this game okay

Where the ♥♥♥♥ is Revelator, Arcsys?  I'll first day buy that ♥♥♥♥ just ♥♥♥♥ing release already.  I guess since I do reviews of stuff in a serious manner I might as well make this half-serious: game is good. The tiers are really, really close and tight to the point where no tier list is agreed upon, as opposed to SFV or KOF2002 whereby the tiers are pretty much set in stone. In other words: all the characters in this game are viable and no one is truly bottom tier (other than Potemkin and Slayer). This game is incredibly well-balanced, which it should be since these characters (minus the new ones) have been getting honed and worked on for close to a decade. Which makes me wonder why the SF characters that have been there since II aren't as balanced and close in terms of tier strength and viability.  There are no clone characters. Every character is unique and your skills with that person doesn't carry over to the other, precisely because they are so unique. The point is better accentuated through contrast: Gouken, Dee Jay, Ryu, Sakura, Dan, Akuma, and Sean are all different characters (with different placement on tier lists). But in many ways they are simply different takes on the same formula: they all have roughly the same inputs for specials and their differences are just that their Dp's and Tatsus are different takes on the same move. It's variations of the same principle; they are all shotos.   GG on the other hand has much more variety in characters and your skills with one won't carry over to another. Some characters have their own unique ''gimmicks'', like Sin's hunger gauge that depletes with every special used but, conversely powers up specials the fuller it is. Venom has pool balls he sets on stage he can teleport to, and all his moves launch them in different trajectories, angles hit also matter. Or Johnnys limited coins for a bout that-oh wait that's in Revelator WHERE THE FU*K IS REVELATOR ARCSYS.  The point is that because the characters are much more varied and different than SF's roster you have to dedicate yourself more to each individual character to truly master them. It took me 70 hours to get a grip on Axl and all the matchups he has; in 100 hours I mained around 8 different characters in SFIV. Granted I'm also much better at GG than SFIV so take that however you wish.  Because each character has their own unique playstyle that doesn't really carry over to any other character your matchup in GG matters more and the manner in which you approach people may drastically change. Against a Venom I know he has projectiles all over the map that hit my hurtboxes, so I rushdown and use my long range normals much more carefully and less frequently (which is REALLY FUC*ING WEIRD FOR AXL); against a KY I make use of my Rensen a lot more just as a pressure tool and don't follow up; against Sol I mind the flames on the floor and am careful with my chains since they have hurtboxes his DP can stuff. Like any fighter your general technique is the same but because there's more variety here in the roster and playstyles you'll find yourself playing much differently depending on the matchup.  I'll end the SF comparison by saying this: ♥♥♥♥ 50/50's. There's none of that bullsh*t ''will he grab or dp on my wakeup'' that some characters in SF have, and thank GOD cause if it's a literal guessing game then eff that.  What there IS here is an EXTREME emphasis on okizeme and mixups/rushdown. This might as well be called, ''okizeme: The Fighting Game''. For those unfamiliar: oki just means your tactics on the enemies wakeup. So after a hard knockdown, what comes next? That's when your pressure game and your mixups come into play; your oki game. This game has a larger emphasis on hard knockdowns and pressure than any other. What this means is that if you're new at this you're gonna get perfected 10 times over; if this game teaches ANYTHING it's how to EFFIN BLOCK.  But if you think turtling all game is great; it's not. Your super gauge (called tension in this game) is completed depleted if you're just holding back all the time. You're penalized for turtling by having your entire gauge erased and by taking even MORE damage from the next hit that connects and isn't blocked.   So not only does this game want you to learn how to block, but it also wants you to do as little of that as possible and to look for holes in offense and counter attack. This makes for fights as hype as MvsC3 fights, except without the touch of death combos due to perforation (reduced damage as the combo continues) and the myriad of defensive options this game has.  You can parry for 1/4'th your tension gauge. You can have your tension gauge slowly deplete if you activate Just Defense, which negates all chip damage. You have Dead Angle Attack, which is essentially a dp for half your gauge (usefulness varies by character). And you can Instant Defend, which builds up tension as you block, by blocking at the proper timing (think of it as SFIII parries, except you press back). There's also Burst, which can be used offensively or defensively. It builds slowly over a match; faster if you're taking damage, but you start with it full at each fights start. Your character jumps up negating all hit or block stun and lets our a burst, hitting your opponent. This can be used to get out of pressure or offensively to gain 100% tension. Whether you need tension more than the defensive option it provides depends on matchup and how confident you feel.  Finally there's roman cancels. You have three roman cancels, which use different amounts of tension but all do the same thing: cancel what you're doing right away. It's SFIV's FADC; only more intuitive and much more central to play. You can do X and roman cancel; you can stand still and roman cancel; you can roman cancel the recovery, but it all costs tension. Depending on the matchup and your character you may need to roman cancel your approach with a projectile of some sort, or you may do a mixup and roman cancel for a continuation. Axl, for example, has a command grab that has range; you can roman cancel it on the enemie's wakeup when they jump to use your anti air chains, so you're essentially doing an unblockable if timed right. But the enemy can jump and roman cancel in the air (roman cancels slow down time slightly), and dash forward with the extra time gained.  So roman cancels are central and can lead to mind games, as well as the creation of space and some cheeky cheeky cheeky plays. In many cases your tension is better put to use with roman cancels rather than supers, although some characters have really good supers that can be used as reversals and are useful in particular matchups (ramlethal can use hers to close the gap with Axl and get up close for a hard knockdown, but she doesn't need it against, say, a Sol).   it's a fantastic anime fighter with a lot of depth to it that makes it fast, hype, but also deep and tactical. It's like MvsC3 or Skullgirls but fast and with a lot of tools and complexity. The online is still alive; albeit GG is nowhere near as popular as the mainstream fighter (since there's really only one) Street Fighter. Mainly because it's much harder to get into any individual character and generally more complex in...everything.   Oh and it brings a 6 hour movie. Overall, amazing game. Extremely deep and quite well balanced fighting game. Quite a few characters have gone MIA in the transition from the XX series, but what is in the game is pretty nice, a good amount of characters for a first installment in the Xrd series, most of them reworked or slightly tweaked for ease of use (except Zato-1 lol).  Graphics are out of this world, and the game ends up beeing pretty demanding due to that, and graphics options in game are quite limited, but messing up with the .ini file lets you tweak it until it works. I'm running it in a notebook lol. There is some info on what to disable on the game Forum, works as a charm. Upon intensive testing after the recent patch, somehow things improvise drastically (Also after reinstalling the game via a steam restore operation due to a need of reformatting, which yielded a reset system settings file for GGXRD). Also tested on another computer with an Asus R7 250X 1GB which performs exactly like the HD 7770 recommended at the store page & it does run like butter on it. Also seems to perform fine on a HD 6850, but there appears to be problems still with some systems, especially laptops for some reason.  To continue, I now get a smooth 60fps across all circumstances in an extended hours of play & the fight pacing is so fast it's like a different game at all. But of course, that's the GG we all knew & love. Thank you Arksys. With this, I wholeheartedly turn the direction of my thumb for this game.  Where to start, okay. Graphics. I'm never for one to care much about it but this game is glorious. 3D which are made to imitate handdrawn drawings can usually still appear 3D, but this game is a game changer in that field. For most of the time you'll be playing this, I bet your ♥♥♥ your mind would think you're playing a 2D fighting game though that's not the case. It doesn't only look like one, but is animated like one too! The devs sure knows how 2D animation techniques works & implemented it flawlessly with the 3D models (suffice to say, that's a damn hard feat).  Next comes the rule book. Basically, the tutorial. Older GG fans know the stuff, but even then this is the first time that there's an actual tutorial explaining what are stuffs like Roman Cancel, Gattling Combination & Dead Angle, their mechanicsm & how to pull them off & in what situation. There is also a challenge mode which is basically where you learn combos & what probable combo chains you can create with them. This also gives newcomers an opportunity to edge up to veteran GG players quicker.  The fighting in GG is also known to be very fast, as in this one & perhaps the fastest in the genre of fighting games, yet it can also get very technical & requires precise input if you're really thinking of beating people. As hardcore as it is, GG is also surprisingly easy to get into. Any beginner can pick it up & could play it pretty well after sometime. Yet it's of those kind which is hard to master. Real mean gattling combos can get very tricky to pull off but the payoff is tremendous as you could juggle or pin down your opponent given they're clueless on how to get out of your mean pushes, but of course- if your opponent knows what he's doing, he can also save himself in many different way, so no unfair edge there.  Characters are also very diversified in terms of gameplay. Characters range from melee to ranged attackers to other weird shenanigans & none plays the same. The only downside to this however it'd take a really long time if you want to master them all as GG is the kind of game where it pays to main a character of your own choosing & play using him/her almost all the time. So take your pick & train hard. And if you play with too many too much, others will surpass you in any given character.  I'd rant longer. But I need to go to sleep but including this & what everyone's saying, it's a great game, simply put. Some of us are luck to not/no longer face bugs with the game, but hopefully continued support is provided & they can fix the problem.

There are some people that play with controllers unsopported but considering that a lot of PC games are totally fine with just 360 pad support and nothing else, I wanna say controller support for this game is actually pretty good.  If your controller is usopported for this game but works fine with your pc for other games, just get xpadder or something, map the controllers buttons to keyboard keys.  Netplay The connections at 1 bar are not as bad as I thought, I have no problem playing most 1 bar opponents, I can deal with a little delay, its fine for me. Sometimes it stutters, and sometimes it feels like fighting in a fishtank filled with pudding, but that's just how it is when you try to play 1 bar players, it's not suppesed to be good. 2 bar usualy has pretty negligible delay for me so I welcome 2 bar players to fight me. It may just be because this is the slowest guilty gear to date, but 3 and 4 bar matches feel prety much perfect.  bugs? Over long netplay sessions the client starts slowing down, I hope this will get fixed soon. Just restart the game and it corrects itself, but expect it to happen again later. I'll keep this review short, as I lack the technical competence to properly judge a fighting game. While I have enjoyed them (and keep enjoying them) since my childhood (Street Fighter 2 being my first entry in the genre), I am definitely just a casual to this day.  With this being said, I believe this is the kind of game that both casuals and more hardcore players can enjoy. The combat is responsive, fluid and enjoyable, the cast of characters is well known by now, but even after all these years it remains a varied and interesting group, and the new entries here and there are enough to freshen things up.  The graphics are marvelous, I can't believe these are 3d models, and the style remains faithful to previous entries in the series. The soundtrack is also amazing, and deserves praise. The story is... Let's say anime ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t? It's kind of fun, as long as you don't think too hard about it (the anime movie that is essentially the story mode is well coreographed and has good direction, though, even if the plot is what it is).   I got this game as a gift, and it has been one of the best gifts ever so far! ^_^ Definitely worth it if you are interested into fighting games (maybe avoid the online scene if you aren't truly dedicated, though, as I assume the players are going to be very competitive, and this is definitely faster and less forgiving than, say, Street Fighter 4, for the uninitiated, and the smaller user base probably makes it even harder to find people of lower skill level).
